subNodes.conversationText: What a meal that was.  It was almost as epic as our adventures together, <FirstName>.
So it was, so it was.  I do love squash--it's a pity one can't have it year round.  That, a pound of butter, and a hogshead of that wine--
Which, I must say, has made me slightly more muddle-headed than I am used to.  There is a pillow in the inn with my name on it.
[Vroman wobbles as he speaks.] To tell the truth, I am also feeling a little tipsy from the wine. Off to bed with me! [Singing.] When that I was a little boy, with heigh ho! The wind and rain...
[Gossam begins to sing too.] A foolish thing was but a toy! For the rain it raineth every day.
I think I shall have a taste of the night air before I turn in.
I will meet you in the inn, then.
[Ianth turns from you and gazes out over the shadowy Backlands.]
[She eventually returns to the inn, and the night passes quietly.]
Perhaps you will allow me to join you for a moment?
It would do me no harm.
You have been even quieter than usual since our encounter in Northdark.
You must understand:  I did not expect to see Marcellus back in the forest and in such circumstances.  The last time I saw him was in Tethyr.
The two of you were lovers?
Ah, you are so frank.  No.  But--
What was your relationship with him?
Would it surprise you to hear that I had feelings for him once?  I suppose not.
What happened between the two of you?
[A look of sorrow passes over Ianth's face.] If only to tell the tale were as easy as that--but in a sense, there is no tale to tell.
He must have done something horrible if you feel this way.
Horrible?  No--no.  It is not as easy as that.  Despite what he seems to be now, he has not wronged me, though my heart might say otherwise.  But please, let me have a few minutes on my own.
Good night then, Ianth.  Will I see you in the inn?
Of course, of course.  Let me have a few moments on my own first, though.
If the subject does not pain you, please tell me more, Ianth.
I appreciate your concern.  Frankly, I am not ready.
Ah.  I have heard enough for the night.
[Ianth turns from you swiftly.] So be it. I will meet you in the Sword and Dragon after a few minutes.
As I said before, he served my father.  I hardly knew him, and yet--
The problems of the region weigh heavily on your mind, I can tell.
If only I were as high-minded as that. They do weigh on me, but I cannot say with truth that something else does not bother me more.
So you were in love with this Marcellus character, I take it?
[Blushing.] Have I been so obvious? It is not like a Sunite to hide her feelings, but these feelings--
You seem genuinely concerned, <FirstName>--your nature, I think, is caring.  I will tell you.
I am thinking of Marcellus, the mercenary we met back in Northdark.  The last time I saw him was in Tethyr.
What is it?  I can sense that something is wrong.
[Hesitantly.] I don't blame you for thinking so, but--ah, by Sune, you are right. Let us talk.
Ah.  Just the sort of opportunity I have been waiting for:  you, me, the starlit sky--
Are you drunk too?  Please, I simply need a moment or two alone.

[Vroman grins sheepishly at you as he speaks.] Off to bed with me--a cold, lonely bed--I'm feeling a little tipsy too, but [Suggestively] not so warm as I'd like. Ah well! I'm drunk--let's talk in the morning, ! [Singing.] When that I was a little boy, with heigh ho! The wind and rain...]
